en: “The devil is in the details,” Jerry says, and back then the devil was him, and these days those details are hard to hang on to.
zh: 「魔鬼就潛伏在細節中。」傑瑞說。說這話時，傑瑞就是魔鬼，這些天所有細節都變幻莫測，很難臨摹和重繪。

en: He can remember the woman’s face, the way her mouth opened when all she could manage was an oh.
zh: 他能回想起那個女人的臉，她張開嘴巴，卻只能發出一聲「噢」。

en: Of course people never know what they’re going to say when their time is up.
zh: 當然，臨終之前，人們永遠不知道該說什麼。

en: Oscar Wilde said something about curtains when he was on his deathbed, about how ugly they were and either they must go or he would.
zh: 據說奧斯卡·王爾德在辭世之前盯著床前的窗帘，他說那些窗帘是多麼醜陋，他正在和它們決一死戰，只有其中的一個才能走，另一個留下。

en: But Jerry also remembers reading that nobody knows for sure if Wilde really said that.
zh: 不過，傑瑞也記得在哪兒讀過，沒有人敢肯定王爾德是不是真的說了這些話。

en: Certainly he wouldn’t have said something pithy if Jerry had snuck into his house and used a knife to pin him to the wall. Maybe a hurts more than I’d thought, but nothing to go down in the history books.
zh: 想象一下，要是傑瑞也潛入王爾德的家中，用刀將他釘在牆上，恐怕他也不會說出什麼發人深省、精闢有力的遺言來，也許他會說：「這一刀比我預料的要更加痛苦。」

en: The policewoman staring at him has a look on her face one would reserve for a wounded cat.
zh: 一個女警官盯著他，臉上的表情像是她收留了一隻受傷的貓咪。

en: Nice long legs, blond hair down to her shoulders, athletic curves and tones. She has a set of blue eyes that keep pulling him in. She’s in a tight, black skirt and a snug-fitting dark blue top that he’d like to see on the floor.
zh: 她雙腿筆直而修長，金髮齊肩，身體曲線婀娜，穿著緊身黑色短裙和修身的深藍色上衣，一雙湛藍的眼眸惹得他心神蕩漾。

en: She keeps rubbing her thumb against the pad of her ring finger, where she’s sporting the type of callus he’s seen on guitar players.
zh: 她拇指不停地揉擦著無名指，撫弄著老繭，這種老繭他曾在一個吉他手的手上見過。

en: Leaning against the wall with his thick forearms folded is a policeman in uniform, an 80s, TV-cop moustache on his lip and a utility belt full of citizen-restraining tools around his waist. He looks bored.
zh: 另一個穿著制服的男警察靠在牆上，粗壯的雙臂交叉在胸前，上唇留著二十世紀八十年代電視上的警察才留的鬍鬚，腰間系著武裝帶，上面掛著槍械等管制工具。

en: I blame cell phones,” he says, and he waits for her to nod and agree, but she doesn’t, nor does the cop holding up the wall.
zh: 現在的人們喜歡以各種千奇百怪的方式寫字，我把這一切都歸咎於手機。」他等著她點頭同意，但她沒有，男警察也只是靠著牆壁，毫無表示。

en: He realizes his mind has once again gone wandering.
zh: 他意識到自己的思緒再次紛飛飄蕩了。

en: He takes a deep breath and tightens his grip on the arms of the chair and repositions himself to try and get more comfortable.
zh: 他深深地吸了一口氣，雙手抓緊椅子的扶手，改變了一下姿勢，好讓自己更舒服些。

en: He closes his eyes and he focuses, focuses, and he takes himself back to Suzan with a z, Suzan with her black hair tied into a ponytail, Suzan with a sexy smile and a great tan and an unlocked door at three in the morning.
zh: 他閉上了眼睛，定氣凝神，把遊離的思緒拉回來，重新回想那個會把「珊」寫成「姍」的蘇姍。那個蘇姍會將一頭烏髮紮成一個馬尾辮，皮膚曬得黑黝黝的，臉上洋溢著迷人的微笑。即便是凌晨三點，蘇姍也不會將門上鎖。

en: A lot has changed in thirty years. Hell, he’s changed.
zh: 不過，三十年了，什麼都變了，傑瑞也變了。

en: But back before texting and the Internet butchered the English language, people weren’t as suspicious.
zh: 但回到當時，簡訊和互聯網還沒有影響到英語語言，人們也不像現在那樣疑心重重。

en: Or perhaps they were just lazier.
zh: 或者，他們也只是比較懶而已。

en: He doesn’t know. What he does know is he was surprised to find her house so easy to get into.
zh: 他還不知道這些，他只知道，她的房子太容易進去了，容易到讓他不可置信。

en: He was nineteen years old and Suzan was the girl of his dreams.
zh: 他當時十九歲，蘇姍是他的夢中情人。

en: “I can still feel the moment,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我仍然能體會到那一刻的感覺。」

en: “I mean, nobody is ever going to forget the first time they take a life.
zh: 傑瑞說，「我的意思是說，沒有人會忘記第一次奪去他人生命的瞬間。

en: But before that I stood in her backyard and I held my arms out wide as if I could embrace the moon.
zh: 在那之前，我站在她家後院，張開雙臂，好像能將月亮攬入懷中。

en: It was a few days before Christmas.
zh: 再過幾天就是聖誕節了。

en: In fact it was the longest day of the year. I remember the clear sky and the way the stars from a million miles away made the night feel timeless.”
zh: 那真是一年當中最漫長的一天，我還記得那個晴朗的夜空，百萬英里之外的星辰讓今夜化為永恆。」

en: He closes his eyes and takes himself back to the moment. He can almost taste the air.
zh: 他閉上眼睛，彷彿回到了那個夜晚，甚至還能嗅到那晚空氣散發的氣息。

en: “I remember thinking on this night people would be born and people would die,” he says, his eyes still closed, “and that the stars didn’t care, that even the stars weren’t forever and life was fleeting.
zh: 「我還記得，當時我想，在這個夜晚有人降生，有人死去，」他說道，雙眼仍然緊閉著，「但星辰是不會在意的。連星辰都不是永生的，何況這白駒過隙的人生。

en: I also remember the urgent need to take a piss, and taking one behind her garage.”
zh: 我還記得當時尿急，就在她的車庫後面撒了一泡尿。」

en: He opens his eyes. His throat is getting a little sore from all the talking and his arm keeps itching.
zh: 他睜開眼睛，說話時喉嚨有點兒痛，手臂也一直覺得痒痒的。

en: There’s a glass of water in front of him.
zh: 他面前放著一杯水。

en: He sips at it, and looks at the man against the wall, the man who is staring at Jerry impassively, as if he’d rather be getting shot in the line of duty than listening to a man telling his tales.
zh: 他抿了一口，抬眼看著倚靠在牆上的男警察，男警察正面無表情地盯著傑瑞，看上去像是寧可在執行任務時被人開槍打死，也不願聽他在這裏啰啰唆唆。

en: Jerry has always known this day was coming, the day of confession. He just hopes it comes with absolution.
zh: 傑瑞知道，懺悔的日子終於還是來臨了，他只是希望能夠得到赦免。

en: After all, that’s why he’s here.
zh: 這就是他在這裏的原因。

en: “Do you know who I am?”
zh: 「你知道我是誰嗎？」

en: the woman asks, and suddenly he gets the idea she’s about to tell him she’s not a cop at all, but the daughter of one of his victims.
zh: 女人問。他忽然意識到，她是要告訴他她並非警察，而是被害人的女兒或者妹妹。

en: “Jerry?”
zh: 「傑瑞？」

en: “Jerry, do you know who I am?”
zh: 「傑瑞，你知道我是誰嗎？」

en: “Of course I know,” he says, staring at her.
zh: 「我當然知道。」

en: That is why you’re here, isn’t it?
zh: 這就是為什麼你會在這裏，不是嗎？

en: For the details?”
zh: 你不就是想聽到那些細節嗎？」

en: “I’m here because—”
zh: 「我在這裡是因為——」

en: He puts his hand up.
zh: 他舉起一隻手。

en: “Enough,” he tells her, the word forceful, and she sighs and slumps back into her chair as if she’s heard that word a hundred times already.
zh: 「夠了。」他鏗鏘有力地說。她嘆了口氣，跌坐在椅子上，好像這個詞她已經聽到過數百次。

en: “Let the monster have a voice,” he says.
zh: 「即便是怪物，也應當有發言權。」他說。

en: He has forgotten her name.
zh: 他已經忘記了她的名字。

en: Detective . . .
zh: 偵探……

en: “Who knows what I will remember tomorrow?”
zh: 「誰知道我明天會記得什麼？」

en: He taps the side of his head as he asks the question, almost expecting it to make a wooden sound, like the table his parents used to have that was thick wood around the edges but hollow in the middle.
zh: 他邊問邊拍了一下頭，期待這一下能發出像敲擊木頭一樣的聲音。他父母曾用過一張桌子，邊緣是厚厚的木頭，中間卻是空的。

en: He wonders where that table is and wonders if his father sold it so he could buy a few more beers.
zh: 他在想那桌子後來到哪裡去了，心裏納悶父親是不是把它賣了，好多買幾瓶啤酒。

en: “Please, you need to calm down,” Detective Scenario says, and she’s wrong.
zh: 「拜託，你需要冷靜。」賽妠瑞爾偵探說。她錯了，他不需要冷靜。

en: If anything he might have to start yelling just to get his point across.
zh: 如果有什麼事值得他聲嘶力竭地大喊，也只是為了清晰明朗地表達自己。

en: “I am calm,” he tells her, and he taps the side of his head and it reminds him of a table his parents used to have.
zh: 「我很冷靜。」他告訴她，又用手拍了一下頭，這又讓他想起他父母曾經用過的那張桌子。

en: “What is wrong with you?” he asks.
zh: 「有什麼不對嗎？」他問，「你傻呀？

en: “Are you stupid? This case will make your career,” he tells her, “and you sit there like a useless whore.”
zh: 這個案子會讓你成就一番事業，」他說，「可你還坐在那裡，像個一無是處的妓|女。」

en: Her face turns red. Tears form in her eyes, but don’t fall.
zh: 她的臉一下子紅了，眼眶裡盛滿淚水，但沒有滴落。

en: He takes another sip of water. It’s cool and helps his throat.
zh: 他又喝了一口水潤潤喉嚨，動作從容瀟洒。

en: The room is silent.
zh: 房間里靜寂無聲。

en: The officer against the wall shifts his position by crossing his arms the other way.
zh: 倚牆而立的警察換了一種姿勢交叉雙臂。

en: Jerry thinks about what he just said and figures out where he went wrong.
zh: 傑瑞思忖著剛才說過的話，看看有沒有說錯的地方。

en: “Look, I’m sorry I said that.
zh: 「聽著，實在抱歉，我說了那些話。

en: Sometimes I say things I shouldn’t.”
zh: 我有時也會口不擇言的。」

en: She wipes the palms of her hands at her eyes, removing the tears before they fall.
zh: 她用手擦擦眼睛，趁著淚水還沒滴落前擦乾它們。

en: “Can I carry on now?” he asks.
zh: 「我可以繼續說了嗎？」他問。

en: “If that will make you happy,” she says.
zh: 「如果你覺得很開心，儘管繼續。」她說。

en: Happy?
zh: 開心？

en: No. He’s not doing this to be happy. He’s doing this so he can get better.
zh: 不，他這樣做不是為了開心，只是為了讓自己好受一些。

en: He thinks back to that night thirty years ago. “I thought I was going to have to pick the lock. I’d been practicing on the one at home.
zh: 他回想起三十年前那個夜晚：「我想我必須把鎖撬開，所以我一直在家練習。

en: I still lived with my parents back then. When they were out I’d practice picking the lock on the back door.
zh: 那時我還和父母住在一起，他們出門后我就開始練習撬後門的鎖。

en: I’d been shown how by a friend from university. He said knowing how to pick a lock is like having a key to the world.
zh: 我上大學的時候，一個朋友曾教我怎樣撬鎖，他說，學會了撬鎖就像擁有了一把開啟世界之門的鑰匙。

en: It took me two months to figure out how to do it, and I was nervous because I knew once I got to her house the lock might be all kinds of different.
zh: 我花了足足兩個月時間才學會撬鎖。但我也很緊張，萬一我去她家，門鎖要是完全不一樣的話我該怎麼辦？結果呢，一切都是徒勞，因為我到了那裡以後才發現她的門根本沒鎖。

en: It was a product of the day, I guess, though that day really was just as violent as this day.”
zh: 我想，儘管那天和今天都充滿了狂風驟雨，但那天還是有所收穫的。」

en: He takes a sip of water. Nobody says anything.
zh: 他又喝了一口水，沒有人搭腔。

en: He carries on. “I never even had doubts.
zh: 他繼續說：「我甚至從來都沒有懷疑過。

en: The door being unlocked, that was a sign and I took it.
zh: 門沒有鎖，這是一個徵兆，而我充分地把握住了它。

en: I had a small flashlight with me so I wouldn’t bump into any walls.
zh: 我隨身帶著一個小手電筒，所以不會撞到牆。

en: Suzan used to live with her boyfriend, but he’d moved out a few months earlier.
zh: 蘇姍的男友曾和她住在一起，但幾個月前就搬出去了。

en: I used to think about her all the time. I imagined how she would look naked.
zh: 我以前總會想她，想象她裸體會是什麼模樣。

en: I just had to know, you know?
zh: 我必須知道，你明白嗎？

en: I had to know how her skin would feel, how her hair would smell, how her mouth would taste.
zh: 我必須知道她的皮膚是多麼細嫩，她的頭髮是多麼柔順，她的嘴唇又是多麼可口。

en: It was like an itch. That’s about the best way to describe it. An itch that was driving me insane,” he says, scratching at the itch on his arm that is also driving him insane.
zh: 這讓我覺得痒痒的——用這個詞描述當時的感覺真是再好不過了，這種痒痒的感覺都快要把我逼瘋了。」

en: “So that night on the longest day of the year I went into her house at three o’clock in the morning with a knife so I could scratch it.”
zh: 「那真是一年中最漫長的一個夜晚，我在凌晨三點鐘走進她家，手裡握著一把刀，這樣我就可以剜掉這塊痒痒肉。」

en: Which is exactly what he did.
zh: 他真的這麼做了。

en: He walked down her hallway and found her bedroom, and then stood in the doorway the same way he’d stood outside, but this time instead of embracing the stars he was embracing the darkness.
zh: 他穿過她家的門廳，找到她的卧室，然後站在門口。他也像這樣站在門外過，但那時他還能面朝星辰，此刻他面前卻只是一片黑暗。

en: He’s been embracing the darkness ever since.
zh: 從那以後，黑暗一直裹挾著他。

en: “She didn’t even wake up.
zh: 「她甚至沒有醒。

en: I mean, not right away.
zh: 我是說，她沒有馬上醒來。

en: My eyes were adjusting to the dark.
zh: 我的眼睛適應了黑暗。

en: Part of the room was lit up by an alarm clock, part was lit up because the curtains were thin and there was a streetlamp outside.
zh: 鬧鐘發出的微光和外面的路燈透過薄薄的窗帘照亮了房間的一角。

en: I moved over to her bed and I crouched next to it and I just waited.
zh: 我走近她的床，蹲在旁邊，等著。

en: I’d always had this theory that if you did that, the person would wake up, and that’s what happened.
zh: 我一直信奉著一個理論，那就是如果你一旦動手了，這人就醒了。

en: “I could feel her breath on my hand, and her eyes . . . her eyes were wide and terrified and made me feel—”
zh: 「我的手可以觸碰到她的呼吸，她的眼睛……她的眼睛睜得大大的，滿是驚恐，這讓我感覺……」

en: “I know all about Suzan with a z,” Detective Scenario says.
zh: 「我知道關於蘇姍的一切。」賽妠瑞爾偵探說。

en: That’s one of the cruel side effects—he’s told her all this before and can’t remember. It’s the details— those damn details that are hard to hang on to.
zh: 這就是殘忍的副作用了——他之前就把一切都告訴過她，但自己不記得了，包括那些細節，那些難以臨摹和重繪的細節。

en: “It’s okay, Jerry,” she says.
zh: 「沒關係，傑瑞。」她說。

en: “What do you mean it’s okay?
zh: 「你說『沒關係』是什麼意思？

en: I killed that woman and now I’m being punished for what I did to her, to all of them, because she was the first of many, and the monster needs to confess, the monster needs to find redemption because if he can, then the Universe will stop punishing him and he can get better.”
zh: 我殺了那個女人，而且她還是我後來眾多受害者的第一個，我殺了很多人，我將因此而受到懲處。惡魔需要懺悔，也需要被救贖，這樣的話，在這宇宙間他將不會再受到懲罰，他也能好受一些。」

en: The detective lifts a handbag off the floor and rests it on her lap.
zh: 偵探從地上撿起一個手提袋，把它放在腿上。

en: She pulls out a book. She hands it to him. “Do you recognize it?”
zh: 她拿出一本書遞給他：「你知道這本書嗎？」

en: “Should I?”
zh: 「我應該知道嗎？」

en: “Read the back cover.”
zh: 「讀一下封底。」

en: The book is called A Christmas Murder.
zh: 書名叫《聖誕節謀殺案》。

en: He turns it over. The first line is “Suzan with a z was going to change his life.”
zh: 他把書翻過來，第一行寫的是「蘇姍將會改變他的生活」。

en: “What in the hell is this?”
zh: 「這他媽到底是什麼？」

en: “You don’t recognize me, do you,” she says.
zh: 「你不認識我了，對嗎？」她說。

en: “I—” he says, but adds nothing more.
zh: 「我——」他說，但接著就不作聲了。

en: There is something there— something coming to the surface. He looks at the way her thumb rubs against the callus on her finger, and there’s something familiar about that. Somebody he knows used to do that.
zh: 有些東西——他好像回想起了有些東西，他看著她的拇指磨蹭著無名指上的老繭，感覺有些似曾相識，他認識的一個人以前肯定經常做這個動作。

en: “Should I?” he asks, and the answer is yes, he should.
zh: 「我應該認識你嗎？」他問。但答案是肯定的，他應該認識她。

en: “I’m Eva. Your daughter.”
zh: 「我是伊娃，你的女兒。」

en: “I don’t have a daughter.
zh: 「我沒有女兒。

en: You’re a cop, and you’re trying to trick me,” he says, doing his best not to sound angry.
zh: 你是警察，你騙我！」他說道，儘力壓制著語氣里的怒火。

en: “I’m not a cop, Jerry.”
zh: 「我不是警察，傑瑞。」

en: “No! No, if I had a daughter I would know about it!”
zh: 「不！不！如果我有女兒，我當然會知道的！」

en: he says, and he slams his hand down on the table.
zh: 他說著，猛地抬手拍桌子。

en: The officer leaning against the wall takes a few steps forward until Eva looks at him and asks him to wait.
zh: 那個靠在牆上的男警察向前邁了幾步，這時伊娃扭頭看他，叫他等等。

en: “Jerry, please, look at the book.”
zh: 「傑瑞，請看一看這本書。」

en: He doesn’t look at the book. He doesn’t do anything but stare at her, and then he closes his eyes and he wonders how life has gotten this way.
zh: 他沒有看書，也沒看別的，只是死死瞪著她，隨後閉上了眼睛。

en: Eighteen months ago things were fine, weren’t they?
zh: 一年半之前一切都很好，不是嗎？

en: What is real and what isn’t?
zh: 可哪些是真的，哪些又不是呢？

en: “Jerry?”
zh: 「傑瑞？」

en: “Eva?”
zh: 「伊娃？」

en: “That’s right, Jerry. It’s Eva.”
zh: 「是的，傑瑞，我是伊娃。」

en: He opens his eyes and looks at the book.
zh: 他睜開雙眼，盯著那本書。

en: He’s seen this cover before, but if he’s read this book he doesn’t remember.
zh: 他以前看見過這本書的封面，但不記得是否讀過。

en: He looks at the name of the author. It’s familiar.
zh: 他看著作者的名字，有些熟悉。

en: It’s . . . but he can’t get there.
zh: 這是……但他想不起來了。

en: “Henry Cutter,” he says, reading the name out loud.
zh: 「亨利·卡特。」他大聲讀出這個人名。

en: “It’s a pen name,” his daughter says, his beautiful daughter, his lovely daughter with a monster of a father, a disgusting old man who moments ago wondered how she would feel beneath him.
zh: 「這是筆名。」他女兒說。他的女兒貌美如花、秀麗可愛，卻有一個怪物般的父親，就在剛才，這個令人厭惡的老男人竟然還在琢磨著要是把她壓在身下，她不知感覺如何。

en: “I don’t . .
zh: 「我不……

en: is this . . . is this you?
zh: 這是……這是你嗎？

en: Did you write this?”
zh: 是你寫的嗎？」

en: he asks. “Did you write this after I told you what happened?”
zh: 他問，「是我告訴了你一切，然後你寫了這本書嗎？」

en: She looks concerned. Patient but concerned.
zh: 她看起來很憂慮，即便耐心的外表也掩蓋不了。

en: “It’s you,” she tells him. “This is your pen name.”
zh: 「是你，」她說，「這是你的筆名。」

en: “I don’t understand.”
zh: 「我不懂。」

en: “You wrote this book, and a dozen more just like it.
zh: 「是你寫了這本書，此外還寫了十二本。

en: You started writing when you were a teenager. You always used the name Henry Cutter.”
zh: 你還是個青少年的時候就開始寫作了，一直沿用亨利·卡特這個筆名。」

en: He’s confused. “What do you mean I wrote this?
zh: 他困惑不已：「你說是我寫的，是什麼意思？

en: Why would I confess to the world what I had done?”
zh: 我為什麼要向世人坦承我做過什麼？」

en: “Did I go to jail?
zh: 「我去坐牢了？

en: Did I write this when I came out?
zh: 出獄以後寫了這些書？

en: But then . . . how would . . . the timeline doesn’t . . .
zh: 但是之後……怎麼會……時間上也不對……

en: I don’t get it.
zh: 我還是不懂。

en: Are you really my daughter?” he asks, and he thinks about his daughter, his Eva, but now that he’s thinking about it, Eva is ten years old, not twentysomething, and his daughter would be calling him Dad, not Jerry.
zh: 你真的是我女兒？」他問。隨後他想起來了，他的伊娃，只不過伊娃才十歲，不是二十來歲。他的女兒會叫他「爸爸」，而不會直呼其名，叫他「傑瑞」。

en: “You’re a crime writer,” she says.
zh: 「你是犯罪小說家。」她說。

en: He doesn’t believe her—why would he? She’s just a stranger. Still . . .
zh: 他不相信她的話，他為什麼……她不過是個陌生人。

en: the crime writer label seems to fit, like putting on a comfortable glove, and he knows what she’s saying is true. Of course it’s true.
zh: 不過……「犯罪小說家」這個名頭似乎完全符合他的身份，就像戴上一副舒適的手套，他知道她所說的是真的。

en: He’s writing another book too. A diary.
zh: 他正在寫另一本書，那是一本日記。

en: No, not a diary, a journal. His Madness Journal.
zh: 不，不單單是本日記，更是狂想錄，是他自己的「狂人日記」。

en: He looks around, but it’s not here with him. Maybe he lost it.
zh: 他環顧四周，發現它不在身邊，也許他把它弄丟了。

en: He flicks through the pages of the book Eva handed him, but not looking at any of the words.
zh: 他翻了幾頁伊娃遞給他的書，但一個字也沒有看進去。

en: “This was one of the early ones.”
zh: 「這是很早以前寫的。」

en: “You have good days and bad,” she says, in the way of an answer.
zh: 「時好時壞吧。」她像背答案似的說。

en: He looks around the room. “Where are we?
zh: 他環視了一下房間：「我們在哪兒？

en: Am I here because of what I did to Suzan?”
zh: 我在這裡是不是因為我對蘇姍做了什麼？」

en: “We found you in town.
zh: 警察說，「我們在城裡發現了你。

en: You were lost and confused.
zh: 你迷路了，而且神志不清。

en: We called your daughter.”
zh: 我們打電話叫來了你女兒。」

en: “There is no Suzan?”
zh: 「沒有蘇姍這個人？」

en: “No Suzan,” Eva says, reaching back into her handbag.
zh: 「沒有蘇姍。」伊娃說著，又拿起手提包，取出一張照片來。

en: She pulls out a photograph. “That’s us,” she says. “It was taken just over a year ago.”
zh: 「這是我們的合影，」她說，「一年前拍的。」

en: He looks at the picture. The woman in the photograph is the same woman talking to him. In the photograph she’s sitting on a couch holding a guitar, a big smile on her face, and the man in the photograph sitting next to her is Jerry, it’s Jerry a year ago, back when all he was forgetting were his keys and the occasional name, back when he was writing books and living life.
zh: 他注視著照片，照片中的女人正是此刻跟他說話的女人，她正坐在沙發上，抱著吉他，燦爛地笑著。

en: His thoughts and memories twisted and decayed.
zh: 隨後，他弄丟了自己，思維和記憶逐漸扭曲，殘缺不全。

en: He turns the photograph over. Written on the back is Proudest dad in the world.
zh: 他把照片翻轉過來，背後寫的是「世上最驕傲的爸爸」。

en: “It was taken the day I told you I’d sold my first song,” she says.
zh: 「拍照那天，我對你說我賣掉了我的第一首歌。」她說。

en: “I remember it,” he tells her, but he doesn’t.
zh: 「我記得。」他說，其實他不記得了。

en: “Good,” she says, and smiles, and in that smile is a lot of sadness and it breaks his heart that his daughter has to see him like this.
zh: 「好。」她笑著說，但笑容里滿是凄楚。讓女兒看到他失魂落魄的模樣，這讓他心如刀割。

en: “I really want to go home now,” he says.
zh: 「我想回家了。」他說。

en: She looks at the officer.
zh: 她看向那位警察。

en: “Is that okay?”
zh: 「可以嗎？」

en: “You’ll need to speak to the nursing home,” the officer says, “tell them this kind of thing can’t keep happening.”
zh: 「你得跟療養院商量一下。」警察說，「讓他們保證這種事情不再發生。」

en: “Nursing home?” Jerry asks.
zh: 「療養院？」傑瑞問。

en: Eva looks at him. “That’s where you live now.”
zh: 伊娃看著他：「就是你現在住的地方。」

en: “I thought we were going home?”
zh: 「我以為我們會回家呢。」

en: “That is your home,” she says.
zh: 「那就是你的家。」她說。

en: He starts to cry, because he remembers it then—his room, the nurses, the gardens, sitting in the sun with only his sense of loss as company.
zh: 他哭了起來，因為他終於回想起了當時的情形——他的房間、護士、花園，他一個人悵然若失地坐在陽光下，形影相弔。

en: He’s not aware he’s crying until his tears hit the top of the table, enough of them to make the officer look away and to make his daughter come around and put her arms around him.
zh: 他不知道自己哭了，直到眼淚掉在桌面上，打濕了一片。那位警察不忍再看，把目光移到別處。女兒走了過來，伸出胳膊抱住了他。

en: “It’s going to be okay, Jerry. I promise.”
zh: 「一切都會好的，傑瑞，我保證。」

en: But he’s still thinking about Suzan with a z, about how it felt back when he killed her, back before he wrote about it.
zh: 但他仍然想著蘇姍，回味著殺死她的感覺，然後又將它化作一個一個字寫下來。
